text: [ELECTRIC BUZZING]
[WHIRRING]
[WHIRRING, DINGING]
[BEEPING]
EMILY GRASLIE: Are we live? Yay!
Welcome, internet, and also the people here.
I never know how to start these things.

Uh... We're... Josh... is a person.
JOSH MATA: Yeah. Hello. My name is Josh,
I'm Collections Assistant of amphibians and reptiles here at the Field Museum and this is a

juvenile alligator that we'll be skinning today.
EMILY: Yes. Yeah,
so I've admittedly never done an alligator, never done any kind of reptile.
Completely out of my element. So why don't you kind of walk us through how this is gonna go.
JOSH: Alright. So first, we're going to roll it over onto its back
and we're gonna make a ventral incision all the way down.

EMILY: Okay.
JOSH: And from there we'll kind of peel it back and go for the feet
and then try to go for the neck area and then we'll do the tail.

EMILY: Tail last.
JOSH: Yeah.
EMILY: Good to know.
Okay, and this guy came from Louisiana.
JOSH: From a wildlife refuge there. We're not entirely sure how it died.
But this was found in our freezer downstairs. It's been sitting in that freezer for ten years.

EMILY: Yeah.
JOSH: What's up?
– Longer than...
– We don't know what kind of smell it will produce when it's opened. So this may be the best odor

this room will have right now.
– All day.
– But we'll find out.
– Yeah, it's an adventure. Why don't I call it olfactory journey?

That's the name of my band.
– All right. All right. So we're gonna start.
– So Josh, how old was this guy? Do you have an estimation?
– This guy or girl. We don't know what gender this is yet.

– Another exciting thing.
– They are probably about three or four years old.
So in maybe three or four more years
they would be old enough to begin reproducing.
– But I've, you know, never seen an alligator this close before.
I think if you got this close to an alligator you'd be kind of having a hard time.
I'm just amazed by all of these scales here.
– Yeah, and then if you feel around the different parts
you can feel the ventral side is a lot smoother and softer than the dorsal side.
– So does this smoothness help them when they're kind of belly crawling?
– Kind of, but it's mostly for protection. So they need more protection

on the upper half of their bodies rather than the lower.
– Gotcha.
– So we're preparing this gator to become a skeleton in our skeletal collection.
JOSH: So the skin and organs we'll still preserve in ethanol.
The skin on reptiles are very important.
As it's used for identification.
Crocodiles and alligators, not so much.
Most people can kind of tell what kind it is from where it's from or other features.
But who knows, maybe in the future the number of scales
the alligator has on its belly can be very important.

EMILY: Okay.
JOSH: So down here, I'm approaching the cloaca
and that's where the alligator's waist and reproductive
organs come out of and so we're going to try and keep the skin intact.
So we're going to go around it and so then when we peel it back it should be still intact on the other side.
EMILY: And we don't know what the sex of this is yet, but once we

begin exploring the cloaca we will find out.
JOSH: Yes. Hopefully it should be quite obvious.
EMILY: Cloaca Exploration is the name of the first track
on my album. What was my band name? I had Olfactory Journey.
JOSH: You should expect album art by the end of the day.
EMILY: So last time someone made, like, the cover art and they even wrote out the lyrics
for one of the songs when we were doing the beaver dissection.
I can't remember what it is but I do have it in a Google Doc on my computer.

What kind of alligator is it?
– It's an American alligator.
And so we got this from Louisiana at a wildlife refuge there.
There are actually only two kinds of alligators living in the world today.
So there's the American alligator, which you get here and Central America
and the Chinese alligator, which is endemic to China.
JOSH: Mm. No.
EMILY: Yeah, that's a good question. So sometimes when we've done mammal dissections in the past
we haven't worn gloves. Sometimes we do.
I think it kind of comes down to personal preference.
With mammals, you know,
we've always found that if you use some sawdust in your bare hands, you can get a better grip on it.
Raven, our production assistant, told me this morning, "oh, by the way,
"alligators can carry West Nile virus. So,
"see ya!" and so for an abundance of caution,
I think, you know...

Zoonosis is a thing.
JOSH: But as for the sawdust, reptile skin
because of the scales is generally very firm anyways so that you don't really...
It's not, like, fluid and loose as much as mammal furs are.
EMILY: Yeah, and the odors really get into your hands, too.

JOSH: Yeah if we weren't wearing gloves we would be smelling like this for, like, the next week.
EMILY: Yeah.
I don't need that. When we did the skunk dissection we wore two pairs of gloves
because you really don't want your hands smelling like skunk butt gas.
JOSH: So the question was "how do you tell the difference between an alligator and a crocodile?"
And it depends if it sees you later or in a while.

EMILY: That was a joke.
– Sorry.
But the main difference is...
So the alligator has a more U-shaped snout.
And here we have a crocodile skull. You can see the crocodile has a more V-shaped snout.
But sometimes some gators just have really thin snouts so that's not a really good way to tell.
So you look on their teeth and the alligators, you notice you can only see the top row of teeth.
You can't see the bottom row. In the crocodiles you can see most of the bottom row teeth,
even when their mouths are closed you'll see the fourth lower tooth is still outside of the mouth.

They have so much muscle and mass in the tail.
EMILY: Oh my gosh.
JOSH: At the very tip of their tail when the muscle starts, you know,
getting less and less, the scales start to get super thick.

EMILY: Oh, wild!
JOSH: So I have to go super slowly to cut down this whole thing.

JOSH: So the question was, what sort of things do Collections Assistants do and how I got the job.
So we are like a library of these animals
so this one is just one of the many books that we have at the Field Museum.
And so researchers from all over the world ask us for these animals,
both skeletons and formalin preserved ones.
And I'm kind of like the librarian in the sense that I provide them with that.
So we'll mail it to them or I'll take photos of them, of what they need, or give them measurements
and they also come here and take their own data from it.

EMILY: Blade Interlude. That's the third track on my album.
— Yes.
So the question was what's the difference between the American alligator and the Chinese alligator?
So the American alligator gets a lot bigger than the Chinese alligator.
The American alligator can grow up to 15 feet long.
— What? Really?

— Yes, we would be here forever if that's how big that alligator was.
— That's longer than this table!

Geez Louise.
— And I think the Chinese alligator can only grow up to seven.
JOSH: Alligators are one of the few reptiles to display parental care.
So the mom will guard the eggs
and then after they've hatched she will guard the young.
And she'll even like bury them on her back or in her mouth.
EMILY: Yeah, you can find videos of that, of baby alligators in the mouth.
And then she just like swims around moving, moving the babes.

I'm glad humans don't do that. That'd be a little weirder.
— Yeah.
[MUSIC RESUMES]

[MUSIC STOPS]
EMILY: Oh, questions from the internet about their feet.
What I thought was interesting is that they have really cute little hands
but only three claws on their fingers

and these two don't have...
JOSH: It would have claws. They would just be underneath the skin.

EMILY: Oh.
JOSH: They could also have not come out yet. But you can feel there is like a nail-type claw.
EMILY: Really?

EMILY: So it's under the skin. Why would it grow like that?
JOSH: I'm not sure.
But another cool thing to point out. So on the front legs, they have five fingers, and on the back they have four.

EMILY: Whoa! I didn't notice!
JOSH: Probably something to do with swimming,
as the back legs are more webbed than the front legs are.
EMILY: They are great swimmers. They can propel themselves through the water at tremendous speeds.
They can also propel themselves using this really big tail with all of this muscle in here.
I mean, it is just muscle. They can propel themselves out of the water.
So if there's, like, something, a monkey or some prey item,
you know, they can basically propel themselves their entire length of their body.
So they'll like get a... I don't know, a swimming start
and then just launch themselves up.
So you can see cool videos on the internet of them doing that, jumping all the way up.
JOSH: There are also really cool videos of them propelling themselves

up fences on land.
EMILY: What?
— So these guys can actually
"climb," but not so much as, like, climbing up,
more or less just pushing themselves up with these really big tails.
— I am increasingly concerned about alligators.
You kind of see them and they look, you know a threatening but a little
slow-moving and innocuous. But they can also run pretty fast.
— So, if they want to, they can just have a burst of energy to chase something down.
— And so they're gonna chase after you and then jump over a fence and so you're... kidding.

They won't do that. 
— No, they're pretty chill.
The question was about how old the families of
crocodiles and alligators are.
So crocodilians in general, which means
all crocodiles and alligators and caimans and gharials,
appeared in the Late Cretaceous era, I believe.

So like 95 million years ago.
— Wow.
— But the alligators and the crocodiles have always been kind of separate from each other.
So they are in separate fam... they're in the crocodilian order but they're in separate families,
with the alligators and Alligatoridae and the crocodilians and

Crocodylidae.
— Crocodylidae?
Crocodylidae, that's the fifth track on my album!
Crocodylidae, that one's gonna have more of a folksy sort of...
Crocodyli... that's like a song you would write for a banjo.
Crocodylidae, dee-dee dee-dee beep, dee-dee beep. See, I'm already laying down the track for you.
Yeah. Yeah. Crocodylidae. That is the most fun word to say.
Crocodylidae!
— So the crocodiles, the Crocodylidae,
that includes all the crocodiles.
The Alligatoridae contains the alligators;
the two alligators that I mentioned, the American and Chinese; as well as all the caimans.
— Alligatoridae is not as fun to say as Crocodylidae.
Crocodylidae, dee-dee dee dee-dee.

– And then you have...
– I'm gonna be hung up on this for a long time.
— And then you have the third group of crocodilians: the gharials or gavials.
We have a skull of one right here.
They are in the family Gavialidae.
And these guys, you can see why they're different from the crocodiles and alligators. They're super weird.
So their skulls are modified for fishing.
So they live in these murky waters and the fish'll be like swimming here
and they can use these to stun them and then just chomp them up.
— So they just, like, swat their head around they'll be like
BAM! hit a fish. And the fish is like, "what hit me?" and then it's like "AHH!" It's in the mouth.

EMILY: I just love the scales. They feel so cool.
JOSH: Yeah.
EMILY: Really smooth.
JOSH: So when people take alligator or crocodilian skins
to make leather they will actually use the belly scales rather than the rest
because of how smooth and uniform they are. Like, you can see they cut really nicely. If we were to do the...
Wait, let me flip it over.
If we were to do the dorsal side, you can see it's very hard and rigid
and has a lot of different patterns, so it's not as easy to make
leather out of it or make a nice design out of it.
So if you ever see any alligator products, they're probably from the belly.
Yeah, so the question was, is there a reason the stomach is easier to skin than the back?
And so that's what we were saying. The skin here is a lot looser
and that's because alligators have this special thing called osteoderms.
So, osteoderms are a bony structure that they have within their skin that makes it super tough.
And so all those osteoderms are on the upper half.
So for that part, we won't be cutting...

we won't be able to cut through this at all.
EMILY: Wow.
Osteoderm is another track on my album, but I think it needs a little bit more work.
Can't just be called Osteoderm.
This is coming right after Crocodylidae so it's gotta have, like, a high impact.
Because that song's gonna be a hit.
JOSH: The osteoderms are under specialized scales called scutes.
You could call it that.

EMILY: Scutes?
JOSH: Scutes.

So scutes are these... can I flip it over one more time?
EMILY: Yep.
JOSH: Scutes are these big block-like scales you see here.
So they're super hard. They're made of keratin.
They're also like this... they're kind of the same thing as, like, the shields on a turtle shell.
EMILY: Oh, cool!
— And so the scutes along with the osteoderms means these guys are super protected and they're very tough.
— Flip it.
JOSH: So when we get to the fingers
we still want to keep all the skin on there.
So we're going to be really careful and we're going to slice down each one

and then kind of peel it back like that.

So kind of a departure from the palm.

JOSH: Yeah. Yeah.
EMILY: That's another track I'll do. Departure From the Palm.

JOSH: It's a long album.
EMILY: I'm the only one amused by that but I think it's funny.
JOSH: Uh, no. So the question was are we going to stuff it and put it on exhibit?
And so we are getting the skeleton out of this to be put into our collection.
The skin, we will preserve in ethanol and will be part of our fluid collection.
So the question was how long does the mother stay with the babies?
Probably just past the juvenile age. So, like, when they're
two feet maybe.
EMILY: Once she can't fit 'em in her mouth anymore.
JOSH: Yeah, and they're too heavy for her back.
EMILY: What's an interesting thing to talk about too is sex determination
in alligators and crocodiles.
So when the mother goes and lays a bunch of eggs,
and she can lay up to, like, 50 eggs at a time, I think you mentioned earlier,
um, they, uh...
The sex of the offspring is determined by the temperature
of the nest and it's a really narrow window of time.
So we had the...
I have the temperatures here, it's cause I couldn't remember them but
below 31 degrees Celsius produces all females,
between 31 and 32.5 degrees Celsius produces majority males
and anything above 32.5 degrees will produce all females.
So, like, you can imagine how, like, climate change might be having a big impact on the ratio of
males to females in alligators and crocodilians,
which is a really interesting thing to explore and to look into.
[MUSIC RESUMES]
[MUSIC STOPS]
JOSH: Yeah, we can talk about those.
Okay, so this first one is an American alligator skull, so what we're doing right now.
This next one is an American crocodile skull.
So here you can really see the difference between the snouts.
So the alligators have a more U-shaped snout and the crocodiles have a more V-shaped snout.
Here we have a yacare caiman.
So the caimans are in the same family as the alligators,
so you see they have this more U-shaped snout,
but they also have these teeth holes that the crocodile has.
So they're kind of like a crocodile-like alligator, but they're alligators.
And then this last one is a false gharial,
which is the last group of crocodilians.
So these are specialized in fishing,
so they have this really long snout so that they can snap fish up from kind of far away.
[MUSIC RESUMES]

[MUSIC STOPS]
JOSH: Oh, good question. So the question was, why are we leaving the skin around the cloaca?
In reptiles the number of scales they have is very important in their identification.
In alligators, not so much, like it's very obviously an American alligator.
The skin and the bones, they will be here for hundreds of years, as long as this museum stands,
so maybe at some point in the future the cloacal scales will be very important for alligator research.

EMILY: How interesting. So are some reptiles identified by their cloacal scales?
JOSH: Yep.

EMILY: Wow.
JOSH: So in snakes especially, they have one big scale near there called the anal scale
and you can tell one snake from another,

depends if it's divided or whole.
EMILY: Wow.
Anal Scales, another track on the album.
JOSH: So, the alligators' sense of vision,
some people say it's almost comparable to an owl's.

EMILY: What?
– They have very good eyesight.
Their photoreceptors in their eyes also allow them to see in the dark
and in their murky waters that they're usually living in.
– So they have great senses, like, highly attuned.
– Oh yeah, highly attuned senses. Now because, hold on, I'm gonna flip it over.
So you can see the eyes are kind of aimed that way.
So they do have kind of a blind spot at the very middle.
But don't trust that of protecting you against an alligator.
Their sense of hearing is also very good. They do communicate with each other.
Alligators more so than crocodiles, actually.

So alligators are able to make these bellowing noises.
– Oh, right.
– And you've probably heard it. If you've seen a Jurassic Park movie,
that's how they get those, like, really low grumbling noises that the dinosaurs make.
– Those are alligator noises?
– Mhm. They're quite scary if you look them up.
And they also make noises low enough that we can't hear them.
But when they're in the water and making these noises,
the volume and frequency of the noises ripples the water around them so it looks like they're farting.

[LAUGHTER]
– "So it looks like they're farting."
– Yeah.

[MUSIC STOPS]
JOSH: In alligators, these aren't ribs that you can see over here, this is the gastralia.
EMILY: Do you see that on the camera?
BOTH: The gastralia.
JOSH: So these are, like, not quite bones, they're, like, cartilaginous fibers
that they have over their belly.
They're not really sure what it's used for, if it's used for breathing or to aid in digestion
or just other general protection of the organs.
But another group of animals that had gastralia are dinosaurs.
So if you go up to the Sue exhibit, that's that new
kind of rib cage-looking thing they've added to their belly.
And alligators and crocodilians have them too.
I like how that was fit.

that this smells like a cow that was fed rotting fish.
So that's a good description. I would agree with that.
Kind of composty, kind of earthy, kind of fishy, aquatic.

JOSH: There are some absolutely horrible smells in the freezer.

EMILY: Oh, that's a good question. The question was, how has skinning this reptile been different than skinning a mammal?
It's not as smelly as mammals.
Mammals have a lot of, they use a lot of
glands and hormones in order to communicate with one another
and they tend to be pretty odiferous.
And then mammals also just kind of stink depending on what they are.
So it's not as smelly as a mammal, which I'm kind of grateful for.
It also is in some ways easier to skin
because you can get, like, a good grip on the skin. It's quite a bit thicker.
It's also more challenging in some ways
because of the scales, because the skin is so thick.
But in general, yes, it's a learning experience for me, too.

JOSH: I think you flicked the skin off.
EMILY: Oh, what did I do, this? Oh.

That was a part of his finger. Do you want to keep that?
JOSH: Yeah, we'll keep it.
JOSH: Yeah, so the question was, when the teeth fall out, do they grow back? Yes.
Alligators and all crocodilians,

I think they could have 80 to 100 teeth at a time.
EMILY: What?
– And they do fall out often when they're fighting.
Whenever they're trying to eat or fighting each other, and they will grow back.

They can go through thousands of teeth in their entire life.
– Really?
[MUSIC RESUMES]

[MUSIC STOPS]
JOSH: So the question was, is there anything unique to their digestive systems?
So alligator stomachs aren't that large compared to their size.
So when they end, but they need to eat large things,
so their stomach acid is very acidic, a lot more than ours, I think.
So to digest things quickly.
But there are things in there that don't digest quickly. So they have trouble digesting
keratin so, like, hair and
turtle shells.
So the hair will actually form kind of like a lump
in their stomach from everything going on which they will spit out.
So alligators can also produce hair balls.
EMILY: Oh, really? Haha, that's kind of funny.
Do they ever find hairballs, alligator hairballs?
JOSH: Yeah, they found alligator hair balls from eating feral pigs.
EMILY: Another title on my track, Alligator Hairballs.
JOSH: And another thing that they have in their stomachs are rocks.

EMILY: Oh!
JOSH: So alligators will purposely swallow stones
to put in their stomach. These are called gastroliths.
They're not entirely sure what their purpose is, whether it's to aid in digestion,
to like kind of crunch things up in there, or if it's like help clean the stomach area.
Some people also think it's useful for diving.
So it makes the alligator heavier, so it helps them in their balance going down.
EMILY: A lot of other, like, dinosaurs would swallow rocks, too.
So you can find gastroliths from, like, giant sauropods
like the titanosaur that we got out in Stanley Field Hall.
So, like, a lot of those long-necked sauropod dinosaurs would also swallow rocks.
You can find fossilized gastroliths. It's kind of neat.
[MUSIC RESUMES]

[MUSIC STOPS]
JOSH: So these large chunks you see here are its cheek and jaw muscles.
So you can see they are quite large and take up a good ch... and it goes deep.
So alligators and all crocodilians have extremely large cheek and jaw muscles
for closing, not for opening.
So if this alligator were still alive and I held it like this it would not be able to open its mouth.
And I'm not exerting that much force into it.
You could tie a rubber band, a fairly large, thick rubber band, and it wouldn't be able to open its mouth.
That being said, if it's shut its mouth and you are in its mouth,
it will not open again.

EMILY: He will not... you will be having a hard time.
JOSH: Yeah.
So the question was, why isn't there any blood?
There is blood, it's just not in the muscle right now and it would be more within the organs.
Reptiles in general also don't bleed as much as mammals do
because of the three-chambered heart.

JOSH: So alligators have this really cool thing in their mouths called the secondary palate.
So the palate is like the roof of our mouths.
So alligators have two rooves in their mouths laying on top of each other.
And so that separates the cavity that the trachea sits in and the cavity that the esophagus sits in.
And so that allows them to breathe while they're underwater.
EMILY: What? Cool.
– This would be the first palate of the alligator.
And then this is the the nostrils and that would be, like, the secondary palate in there.
So it would go, they would, like, breathe air through there and then it comes out here,
into the trachea.
The brain would be somewhere in there.

– Very small.
– Yes.
